metadata.case_name: Executors of the will of Mr. J.K. Dubash v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Mr. J.K. Dubash died on the 9th of April, 1942, having made his last will on the 8th of April, 1942.
Probate of the will was issued to the executors on the 10th of August, 1942.
During his lifetime, the testator carried on the business of shipping agents.

Clause 13 of the will directs the executors to carry on the business as a going concern after his death with power to make fresh contracts and discharge existing and future liabilities, unless special circumstances made it expedient to sell earlier.
The business was to be carried on for a period not exceeding twelve months during which time the executors were to ascertain whether any of his nephews was willing to purchase the said undertaking.

Executors directed to have a valuation made of the undertaking as soon as possible after death for sale purposes, including premises, goodwill, stock-in-trade, plant, furniture etc., excluding securities and cash.
If not sold to nephews within one year or at end of year, sell to third person on terms and price as executors thought proper.
Executors have power to carry on or discontinue any part, augment or diminish capital, act as absolute owners without responsibility for loss.
The business was sold to one of the nephews on the 1st of January, 1943.
Appellants contended that succession to the business took place on 1st January, 1943; taxing authorities contended on 9th April, 1942.
Second question on amount paid by executors to widow of testator, answered against appellants by High Court, not contested in appeal.

Reference by Income-tax Appellate Tribunal under section 66(1) of Indian Income-tax Act, Income Tax Reference No. 26 of 1947, judgment of Bombay High Court by Chagla C.J. and Tendolkar J. dated March 19, 1948.

legal_issues.text: Whether succession to the business within the meaning of section 25(4) of the Indian Income-tax Act took place on the death of the testator on 9th April 1942, or on the sale of the business on 1st January 1943.

petitioner_arguments.text: On death of testator, under clause 13 of the will, executors carried on business only for purpose of winding it up, no succession within s.25(4); directions only to sell within year to nephew or as going concern to third party.
Powers to make contracts etc. only to keep business alive as going concern for sale with goodwill; succession only on sale to nephew on 1st January 1943.

respondent_arguments.text: Succession took place on 9th April 1942 when testator died.

court_reasoning.text: On death, estate including business vested in executors; they carried on business within s.3 read with s.10, became liable as assessee; change in assessee means succession in such capacity under s.25(4).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Executors carried on business as going concern, liable for tax personally.

court_reasoning.text: Analogy: Succession on sale/gift occurs on date of transfer; on intestate death, heir succeeds on death date; similar for executor by operation of law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legal estate transfer to executor is succession, 'in such capacity' makes legal/benficial ownership irrelevant.

court_reasoning.text: S.25(4) relief governed by words used; succession to another person occurred on death.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Business carried on for estate's benefit irrelevant; focus on succession to person carrying on business.

court_reasoning.text: Patanjali Sastri J.: S.25(4) consequential on amendment to s.26(2); succession includes on death per s.24B; 'in such capacity' means capacity of carrying on business as principal liable to tax, not necessarily ownership transfer.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Executors as association of persons carrying on business post-death, assessable under s.10 r/w s.3.

court_reasoning.text: No insistence on ownership transfer; liability on person carrying on business regardless of enjoyment; precedents support focus on receiver/controller.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Executors succeeded testator in capacity of carrying on business.

holdings.text: Succession under s.25(4) occurred on 9th April 1942, date of testator's death; exemption only for profits from 1st April to 9th April 1942.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. P.E. Polson
precedents_cited.relevance: Reason for relief under s.25(4): change in taxation basis by 1922 Act leading to double taxation on 1921-22 profits.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jupudi Kesava Rao v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Held 'in such capacity' means as owner; court disagrees, no essential ownership transfer needed.
Person charged is in actual receipt and control of income, not trustee or beneficiary as such.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: S.25(4) provides relief on succession; linked to s.26(2) apportionment; succession on death to executors; liability on carrier-on of business.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1918
statutes_cited.relevance: Business charged to tax under this Act, basis for s.25(4) relief.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Amendment Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Changed basis of taxation, causing double taxation on 1921-22 profits, occasion for relief.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax (Amendment) Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended s.26(2) for apportionment on succession, extended relief via s.25(4).

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court correct that succession under s.25(4) occurred on testator's death on 9th April 1942; appellants not entitled to exemption for period beyond that date up to sale.

key_quotes.text: Thus there came about a change in the assessee and therefore a succession in such capacity took place within the meaning of section 25(4) of the Income-tax Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on succession to executors on death.

key_quotes.text: The words 'in such capacity' in that clause further make the position clear. It makes the distinction of legal and beneficial ownership irrelevant.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies meaning of 'in such capacity' under s.25(4).

key_quotes.text: The Income-tax Act directs its attention primarily to the person who receives the income, profits or gains rather than to the ownership or enjoyment thereof.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains focus on carrier-on of business, not ownership.

key_quotes.text: The words 'in such capacity' in sections 25(4) and 26(2) mean nothing more than the capacity of a person who carries on the business as the predecessor was carrying it on that is, with a liability to be taxed on its profits and gains.
key_quotes.speaker: court
